title: The death of the British gooseberry is nigh
text:

Mon, Aug 3, 2015, 19:24 BST - UK Markets closed The death of the British gooseberry is nigh By Rebecca Burn-Callander | Telegraph – 5 hours ago Print 
The heritage gooseberry is set to follow the British loganberry into oblivion 
The British gooseberry is in danger of disappearing from UK grocers for good, it has emerged, as demand for the soft fruit reaches its lowest level ever. 
The green fruit, which had its heyday in the early 1900s, is now grown by just a handful of UK farms, down from more than 100 in 1990. 
"It's one of the old English fruits that's now in danger of disappearing totally ," said Stephen Taylor, one of the last commercial gooseberry farmers in the country. 
"Raspberries, strawberries, blueberries and blackberries now dominate the market and minor fruits are being forgotten." 
Over the past two decades, farmers have invested heavily in extending the season for popular soft fruits, such as the strawberry . 
In addition, mainstream berries are imported from all over the world to ensure a year-round supply. 
"These has been no investment in gooseberries," said Mr Taylor. "Their season is extremely short: they're here and gone in the space of a month." 
There are just three weeks remaining of the current gooseberry season. 
There are two kinds of gooseberries: the tart, cooking variety typically used for crumbles, and the sweet, dessert gooseberry, which can be eaten raw. 
"Young people don't know the difference now, which makes it even more difficult to sell the fruit," said Mr Taylor. 
Waitrose is one of the few supermarkets that is still stocking both varieties of gooseberry. However, prices are still too low to ensure the survival of the fruit. 
"It would solve the problem overnight if we could double the price," said Mr Taylor. "At £2 for a 400g punnet, we can't afford to invest in the fruit." 
The gooseberry fool is a traditional English recipe 
Supermarkets are reluctant to take a risk on a fruit with such a short shelf-life, Mr Taylor claimed. "You're trying to get buyers to put something on shelves for just four weeks and they need to make a certain amount of money per square foot." 
In order to sell gooseberries to the supermarkets, farmers must ensure they have all the correct paperwork in place regarding provenance and farming practices. "All that for a few tonnes of gooseberries, it's not worth it for many," said Mr Taylor. 
The gooseberry is one of the first fruits ever cultivated commercially in this country. The first farms began growing the fruit in the 1600s when there were 2,000 different varieties in the UK. 
There are now just 20 varieties of gooseberry grown in this country, and only seven are cultivated by commercial farms. 
Many varieties of British gooseberry were destroyed by a disease known as American Gooseberry Mildew, which was spread when infected American gooseberries were imported at the beginning of the 20th century. 
Mr Taylor has been growing gooseberries on Winterwood, his family farm near Maindenhead, Kent, since 1978. 
"We started out as a small grower so we decided to do all the minor fruits as a point of difference," he explained. "Today, we grow about 150 tonnes of gooseberries a year." 
Winterwood farm also specialises in other rare minor fruits, such as whitecurrants, redcurrants, blackcurrants. Blueberries are the mainstay of the £28m-turnover farm. "We send blueberries all over the country but the irony is that the blueberries pay for us to transport the minor fruits, otherwise we couldn't afford to move them around the country." 
The loganberry is a relative of the raspberry (PhotoLibrary) 
There are fears that the gooseberry might follow other heritage berries into the history books. 
"We were the last commercial farm to grow loganberries for the supermarkets," claimed Mr Taylor. "They haven't been sold for 10 years now. 
"The gooseberry might go the same way. The odds of us growing them in 20 years time is about 50/50 right now."
